title: The Sunkoshi-Marin Tunnel brings much-needed water to farms in the dry Madhesh region, giving farmers hope for a better future.
content:
**Sunkoshi Marin Project**

This project aims to provide water for farming in central Tarai, an area that often faces drought.

**Key Features:**

* A 13.3 km tunnel to divert water from the Sunkoshi River to the Marin River.
* A 31.07 megawatt hydroelectric power plant.
* Irrigation for 122,000 hectares of land in five districts.

**Timeline:**

* Tunnel completed in January 2023, six months ahead of schedule.
* Project expected to be finished in July 2027.

**Benefits:**

* Improved irrigation, leading to increased crop production and income for farmers.
* Hydroelectric power generation.
* Economic opportunities in the Tarai region.

**Cost:**

* Total project cost is estimated at Rs87 billion.
* Tunnel construction cost: Rs10.05 billion.

**Environmental Impact:**

* The project will flood some land and relocate a portion of a highway.
* Year-round irrigation is expected to boost agricultural productivity and reduce food shortages.

title: Nepali Congress might allow Rabi Lamichhane, the leader of Rashtriya Swatantra Party, to speak in parliament despite his citizenship case being under investigation.
content:
**Nepali Congress Demands Investigation of Home Minister**

The main opposition party, Nepali Congress, refuses to back down from its demand for a parliamentary investigation into Deputy Prime Minister and Home Minister Rabi Lamichhane.

Lamichhane is accused of stealing money from credit unions. Police reports show large amounts of money were transferred to his name without permission.

Nepali Congress claims Lamichhane used the police and Attorney General's office to pretend he is innocent. They believe he is afraid of being punished if he is fully investigated.

The government has called a special Parliament session, but the parties disagree on how to handle the investigation. The opposition wants a committee solely focused on Lamichhane, while the ruling parties want a broader investigation of the entire credit union industry.

The opposition is blocking Parliament proceedings until the government agrees to their demand. They also say they will prevent Lamichhane from speaking in Parliament until the investigation begins.

The Nepali Congress also discussed the political situation in some provinces where the ruling parties are facing challenges forming governments. They expressed concern about unconstitutional actions and are considering legal action.

content:

title: Prime Minister inaugurates the breakthrough of the Sunkoshi-Marin diversion tunnel, a major project that will divert water from the Sunkoshi River to the Marin River for irrigation and hydropower generation.
content: A huge tunnel has been built in Nepal called the Sunkoshi-Marin Diversion Multi-purpose Project. The tunnel is over 13 kilometers long and runs from Kusumtar to Kanadhungri. The tunnel took 19 months to build, which is one year faster than planned. A dam will be built at Kanadhungri to store water, which will then flow through the tunnel to Kusumtar. The water from the tunnel will be used to generate electricity and provide water for irrigation to five districts in Nepal. The tunnel cost about 10 billion rupees to build.

title: President attends a special event to celebrate Law Day.
content:
**Law Day Celebration in Nepal**

On Wednesday, Nepal celebrated Law Day with events across the country. The Supreme Court held a special ceremony, which was attended by the President, Prime Minister, Speaker, and other officials.

Chief Justice Bishwambhar Prasad Shrestha gave a speech wishing everyone a good Law Day and emphasized the importance of following the constitution, laws, and human rights. He also said that the judiciary, the Attorney General's Office, and the Nepal Bar Association need to work together to ensure justice is served effectively.

Law Day in Nepal commemorates the introduction of the Chief Court Act in 2008, which established an independent judiciary and separated the powers of the government.

The event was attended by the Vice President, Prime Minister, Speaker, and other high-ranking officials, as well as judges, lawyers, and media representatives.

title: The president attended a celebration honoring Law Day, which recognizes the importance of law and the rule of law.
content:
On Wednesday, Nepal celebrated Law Day (Law Day 2081 BS) with events nationwide.

The Supreme Court held a special program attended by the President, Prime Minister, Speaker, and other officials. Chief Justice Bishwambhar Prasad Shrestha expressed hope that this day would inspire everyone to create a society where the Constitution, rule of law, and human rights are fully protected.

The Chief Justice emphasized the importance of ongoing judicial reforms, highlighting the need for collaboration with stakeholders such as the Attorney General's Office and Nepal Bar Association.

Law Day commemorates the establishment of the Chief Court Act in 2008 BS, promoting an independent judiciary and separation of powers.

The event was attended by senior government officials, legal professionals, and media representatives.

title: Today is Mother's Day, a special day to honor and celebrate mothers.
content:
Today is Matatirtha Aunsi, Mother's Day in Nepal. People show their love and respect for their mothers.

On this day, people take baths and offer gifts and food to their mothers. They also remember mothers who have passed away by performing a special ritual called shradda.

According to Hindu beliefs, honoring mothers is very important. It is thought to bring good luck and free people from any unpaid debts to their mothers.

There is a fair at Matatirtha Kunda today in memory of mothers. It is believed that taking a dip in the pond there can help people pay off their maternal debt.

title: Repairs and rebuilding of the historic Thanthu Durbar, which was built during the Malla era, have started.
content: A historic palace in Bhaktapur called Thanthu Durbar is being rebuilt after it was damaged. The palace was built 346 years ago. Officials said the rebuilding will cost about 128.5 million rupees. They also said that old houses in Bhaktapur should be checked to make sure they are safe to live in. content:
The Nepali Congress Party (NC) is unhappy with the government for ignoring their concerns. They want the government to investigate a scandal involving money from cooperatives.

content:
Prime Minister Prachanda asked minority groups to unite to protect their rights and finish implementing laws on identity and other national issues.

He believes these groups should work together to identify real representatives who fight for their rights.

Prachanda said that his party helped fight for these rights in the constitution and appeals to minorities to show support for the implementation of these laws.

title: Nepal plans to take legal action.
content:
**Janata Samajwadi Party (JSP) to Fight Party Split Legally**

JSP, led by Upendra Yadav, plans to take legal action against a group that has split from the party. The split group, led by Ashok Rai, has been recognized as a separate party by the Election Commission.

JSP's leaders have decided to hold a meeting on Wednesday to discuss the split and decide on legal actions. After the meeting, they will hold a press conference to make their decision public.

title: A leader named Oli sees a need for the left-leaning parties to come together.
content:
**Summary:**

Former Prime Minister KP Oli, leader of the CPN (UML) party, urged all leftist political parties in Nepal to unite under his party.

Oli said his party wants to be a strong national force and will focus on unity, organization, and policies, not emotions.

He also talked about the recent by-election results, which he saw as a sign of success for his party in the upcoming parliamentary election.

Former leader Siddinath Gyawali was remembered for his integrity and dedication, and Oli said he had a good relationship with him.

content:
**Earthquake Relief in Nepal**

The government wants to help those who lost their homes in the earthquake in November. They need to get money to rebuild their homes as soon as possible.

The government knows that Nepal has many disasters like landslides and floods. They want to create plans to reduce the damage from these disasters.

The government has an organization called the National Risk Reduction and Management Authority. They have helped rebuild after the earthquakes in Karnali Province.

The government needs to work with the province and local governments to send help to disaster-affected areas, but sometimes they don't have enough money.

Karnali Province needs over 100,000 new houses to be built.

content: A mother and her son died in a fire in Siddhicharan, Nepal. The mother tried to put out a fire in a forest when she caught fire. Her son tried to save her but also died. Police and firefighters are on the scene. There have been other fires in the area recently.

title: Twenty-four artifacts were sent from Hawaii to Nepal.
content:
Nepal's embassy in the USA received 24 ancient artifacts from Ms. Bradford and sent them to the Department of Archaeology in Nepal. These artifacts were from Ms. Bradford's private collection. Most of them date back to the 17th and 18th centuries, with a few from the 13th century. Ms. Bradford paid for the shipping to Nepal.

The embassy thanked Ms. Bradford for returning the valuable artifacts. This inspired others to return lost Nepali heritage.

The embassy has been working with Nepal and US officials, art experts, and individuals to recover and return lost Nepali art. Including these 24 artifacts, the embassy has sent a total of 63 artifacts back to Nepal in the past year.

Both countries have been working together in many ways for a long time.

title: Japan and Nepal have many similarities, according to Japan's Foreign Minister Kamikawa Yoko.
content:
**Similarities between Japan and Nepal:**

* Both have mountainous terrain (70-80%).
* Both are democratic countries.

**Cooperation between Japan and Nepal:**

* Japan has supported Nepal's democratization efforts.
* Japan has assisted in rebuilding after earthquakes in both countries.
* Both countries lack natural resources and value connectivity.

**Japan's Support for Nepal's Development:**

* Japan has provided over 32 billion yen for reconstruction after earthquakes.
* Japan is constructing the Nagdhunga tunnel, Nepal's first mountain road tunnel.
* Japan supports infrastructure, agriculture, education, and healthcare in Nepal.

**Nepal's Growing Presence in Japan:**

* Over 170,000 Nepalis live in Japan.
* There are direct flights between Japan and Nepal.

**Cooperation on "Women, Peace and Security" (WPS):**

* Japan promotes WPS, which involves women in peace efforts and protecting vulnerable groups.
* Nepal has many female peacekeepers.
* Japan and Nepal are exploring cooperation in WPS.

**Future Goals:**

* Japan wants to strengthen its relationship with Nepal and support its development.
* 2026 marks the 70th anniversary of diplomatic relations and Nepal's graduation from LDC status.

title: not-to-go-to-foreign-employment-through-illegal-route-embassy
content:
The Embassy of Nepal in Islamabad has urged all the concerned to only use legal means to go for foreign employment, noting many Nepali have been victimized and stranded in Kyrgyzstan for some time on temptation of attractive jobs.The embassy said it has received information that some of those victimized have been assured to be sent to other countries using Kyrgyzstan route, sharing that some of the stranded people have been rescued and sent back to Nepal, some are on their way back but the process of reaching there has not stopped.
In a statement issued on Tuesday, the embassy said, "As per the information received, some Nepali and foreigners are being involved in the fraudulent acts in the face of lucrative jobs".
Individuals and groups involved in illegal activities of taking Nepali citizens abroad on the wrong temptation and leaving them stranded have to face the prevailing law, the statement further noted.
"The embassy sincerely requests all concerned not to fall prey to the ill-intended act of fraudulent groups and to use only the established and legal route arranged by the Government of Nepal to go for foreign employment", the statement reads.

title: Minister Bhandari says that Dailekh will start on the path to economic prosperity.
content:

The Minister of Industry and other officials opened the final part of the petroleum exploration in Dailekh district. They hope the exploration will be successful and bring economic prosperity to Nepal.

If petroleum and gas are found in large enough quantities, Dailekh could become a major economic center in Nepal. The exploration is being funded by the Chinese government.

The results of the exploration will be known in six months. If there are enough resources, the government will move forward with plans to extract and process the petroleum and gas.

title: Nepalese runners won two titles in Malaysia.
content:
**Mahadev Rijal Wins Running Races in Malaysia**

Mahadev Rijal, a runner from Nepal, won two races in Malaysia. He won both the 21 km half marathon and Climbathon event.

In the half marathon, he finished in 1 hour, 14 minutes, and 48 seconds. In the Climbathon event, he finished in 3 hours, 3 minutes, and 58 seconds.

Rijal has won races in Malaysia before. Last year, he came in 8th place in the Tower Runner race, which had 284 participants.

title: Dengue fever cases in the Bagmati province of Nepal have exceeded 11,000.
content:
**Dengue Fever in Bagmati Province**

There have been a lot of cases of dengue fever in Bagmati Province in the last 9 months. Over 11,000 people have been diagnosed with dengue in the province since July 17, 2023.

Most of the cases were in Dhading, with over 3,500 cases. Kathmandu, Chitwan, and Makwanpur also had a lot of cases.

One person in Makwanpur died from dengue this year.

Dengue is spread by mosquitoes, and it's more common in the summer. The health department in Bagmati Province is planning to launch a campaign to kill mosquito larvae and stop the spread of dengue.

title: Nepal believes everyone should have the rights and opportunities needed to live a good life. This means access to education, healthcare, and other important services, regardless of who they are or where they live.
content:
**Nepal Adopts Rights-Based Approach to Population and Development**

Nepal believes that everyone has the right to live a healthy and fulfilling life. This includes having access to healthcare, education, and other services that improve quality of life.

Nepal is working to achieve the United Nations' Sustainable Development Goals by putting people's needs first. These goals include reducing poverty, improving health, and promoting gender equality.

Despite progress, challenges like pandemics and climate change make it difficult to reach these goals. However, Nepal remains committed to ensuring that everyone has the opportunity to live a good life.

title: Japan has given a community center to a place where people can go in case of a disaster.
content:
Japan has given Indrawati Rural Municipality a new community center to help them get ready for disasters. The Japanese government gave the money to build the center through a program for Japanese non-profit groups.

The Japan Asian Association & Asian Friendship Society (JAFS) is working on the project, which will not only build the center but also set up disaster prevention groups, activities, and public announcements. It will also build warehouses and take steps to stop landslides.

Japan's ambassador said he hopes the new center will become a place where people can learn about disaster prevention and make the area better as a whole.

title: Dr. Sharma, a member of parliament, donated 2 million rupees to the Children's Hospital.
content:

title: Nepali bureaucracy is a complex system with many levels of government. There are many different ministries and departments, each with their own responsibilities. The bureaucracy can be difficult to navigate, and it can be challenging to get things done.
content:
**Nepali Bureaucracy: Two Sides of the Coin**

Bureaucrats in Nepal are seen in two different ways:

**1. Powerful and Independent:**
Bureaucrats are thought to be a powerful group with the ability to challenge politicians.

**2. Subservient and Corrupt:**
Bureaucrats are also seen as subservient to politicians, working together for personal gain.

**How can both be true?**

Bureaucrats have more options now than before. They can:

* **Resist:** Refuse to follow orders they believe are wrong.
* **Maintain the Status Quo:** Do as they've always done, without making changes.
* **Collude:** Work with politicians for personal benefit.

**Post-Monarchy Changes**

Bureaucrats have gained more power after the end of the monarchy because:

* A new law in 1993 protects bureaucrats from being fired without reason.
* Bureaucrats formed trade unions to represent their interests.
* Politicians are often relying on bureaucrats for support.

**Implications and Solutions**

Excessive bureaucratic power can hinder good governance. Reforms are needed to:

* Abolish party-based trade unions for bureaucrats.
* Reduce bureaucratic influence on promotions and transfers.
* Tie promotions to work performance.

However, the weak quality of elected representatives and political instability have allowed bureaucrats to increase their power.

title: Massing of Education refers to the concentration of educational institutions and resources in certain locations, such as big cities or university towns. It typically results in a high density of students, faculty, and educational facilities in those areas.
content:
**Mass Higher Education: A Post-World War II Idea**

After World War II, the idea of mass higher education emerged, aiming to expand access to higher education for social equality. The UK and USA led this expansion, fostering the development of a new industry in education.

In the 1960s, the concept of "human capital" redefined higher education as a valuable investment for economic growth. This idea, backed by corporate and international organizations, became a driving force behind the massive expansion of higher education.

However, this expansion came with costs. Admission standards declined, and academic content was watered down to accommodate students with lower abilities. This led to a decline in the overall quality of higher education.

Despite the claims that mass higher education would boost economic prosperity, it has instead created a crisis of quality. Employers struggle to find qualified employees among the large number of graduates, and there is a shortage of researchers and innovators.

The emphasis on vocational skills over academic knowledge has also led to a decline in original research and intellectual advancement.

**Drones Could Affect Sherpa Jobs**

The use of drones could affect the livelihoods of Sherpa guides, who carry supplies and navigate the dangerous Khumbu Icefall on Everest. Avalanches and falling ice are common dangers on the icefall, and drones could reduce the number of casualties among guides.

**Drone Test and Pilot Program**

The Khumbu Pasang Lhamu Rural Municipality is testing drones that can fly up to 6,500 meters and carry 30 kilograms. If the test is successful, drones will be used to bring garbage from Camp II (6,400 meters) to the base camp next season.

**Other Rules to Improve Safety and Reduce Garbage**

In addition to using drones, new rules have been implemented to make climbing Everest safer and reduce garbage. These include:

* Climbers must wear a tracking chip or GPS device.
* People at base camp are allowed a maximum of 80 square feet per person to sleep in.
* Attached toilets are not allowed in sleeping tents.
* Climbers must use poop bags above the base camp.
* Climbers must bring back all used poop bags and 8 kilograms of garbage to receive a refund of their garbage deposit.
* Commercial activities like bars and spas are not allowed at base camp.
* Lights must be turned off at night except in emergencies.

The Department of Drug Administration (DDA) checks the quality of medicines sold in Nepal. Over the past 9 months, they have tested only 348 samples from thousands of medicines available in the market.

Out of those tested, some were found to be substandard and removed from stores. However, DDA admits that they have not tested enough samples to ensure the quality of all medicines.

As a result, patients may have taken substandard medicines without knowing. This can be dangerous for their health.

DDA is responsible for ensuring medicine quality, but they need more resources and staff to do this effectively.

title: toxic-air-is-giving-young-children-asthma
content:
**Air Pollution and Childhood Asthma in Nepal**

Air pollution has been getting worse in Nepal, causing a lot of children to get asthma.

A recent study found that air pollution:

* Causes asthma, coughing, and other health problems in children and women
* Can even make women lose their babies or have babies born with smaller organs
* Shortens people's lives by about five years

Children are most affected by air pollution because their lungs are still developing. Asthmatic children may have trouble breathing, sleep, or play.

Other things like allergies and family history can also cause childhood asthma.

It's important to take children to the doctor if they have trouble breathing, coughing, or wheezing. If asthma is not treated, it can damage their lungs.

Air pollution is a serious problem in Nepal. It's making people sick and shortening their lives. We need to find ways to improve the air quality so our children can have a healthy future.

title: Nepal could not meet its 2025 goal to eliminate malaria. The new target date may now be 2030.
content:
**Nepal's Malaria Elimination Goal Delayed**

Nepal planned to be malaria-free by 2026, but it has now missed the target due to new malaria cases in 2023 and 2024.

Malaria is caused by parasites spread by infected mosquitoes. Local malaria cases (called "indigenous") mean the infected person did not travel to a malaria-affected area.

In the last year, Nepal had 528 malaria cases, including 23 indigenous cases. Most imported cases came from India, Africa, and from Nepalese soldiers on peacekeeping missions.

Eliminating malaria in Nepal is difficult because it is close to India, where malaria is still present. Other challenges include:

* Changing climate causing mosquitoes to spread to higher altitudes
* Cuts in health funding
* Lack of trained health workers
* Other factors like poverty and lack of education

Until India eliminates malaria, it will be difficult for Nepal to do the same.

content:
**China's Aging Population Faces Low Retirement Income**

Many older Chinese who worked in cities are returning to the countryside as they retire. However, they only get a small pension of $17 per month.

The government prioritizes economic growth over social security. China's pension system is divided into urban and rural, with urban pensions being much higher.

Economists suggest that increasing pensions for the poorest Chinese would boost domestic consumption. However, the government has only increased the minimum pension by $3 per month.

The Chinese government plans to raise the retirement age but is worried about how people will react. Meanwhile, many elderly Chinese are forced to work low-paying jobs to survive.

Traditionally, children were expected to support the elderly. However, most of the retiring generation only have one child due to birth limits. Also, many young people today are struggling to find jobs.

As a result, China's elderly population may face a drop in living standards and difficulty in accessing healthcare.

title: Flooding in Brazil has left 150,000 people without homes and many dead or missing.

Torrential rains caused devastating floods in southern Brazil, especially in the state of Rio Grande do Sul.

At least 90 people have died, and thousands are homeless. People are sleeping on the streets, hungry and desperate for supplies.

Rescue efforts are difficult due to the flooding. Dozens of people are still stranded in their homes, waiting to be rescued by boat or helicopter.

The floods have damaged roads and bridges, and destroyed homes and businesses. Over 1.4 million people are without water and electricity.

Climate change is making extreme weather events like this more frequent and intense. The rains were caused by a combination of factors, including warm ocean waters and a weaker cold front.

The Brazilian government is providing aid to the affected areas. The impact on the economy is expected to be small, but there may be higher prices for rice.

The flooding has also damaged grain fields and meat plants, disrupting the harvest and livestock production.

title: Foreign books in Nepal are being illegally translated and pirated, which means they are being made available for the public without the permission of the original creators. This is a problem because it can lead to loss of income for the creators and publishers, and it can also damage the reputation of the publishing industry in Nepal.
content:
**Unauthorized Book Translations in Nepal**

In Nepal, unauthorized translations of popular books are common. Writers like Taslima Nasrin and Shiv Khera have had their works translated without their consent. Unapproved translations have also been published for books like "Steve Jobs" and "Rich Dad Poor Dad."

**Impact on Quality**

These unauthorized translations are often of poor quality, with pages removed or content altered. This hurts both authors and readers, who may not be aware of the errors.

**Legal and Ethical Violations**

Translating and publishing books without authorization is illegal and violates copyright laws. It also goes against ethical standards, depriving authors of revenue and recognition.

**Negative Impact on the Publishing Industry**

Unauthorized translations damage the credibility of Nepal's publishing industry. They make it difficult for legitimate publishers to compete and discourage original works from being translated.

**Reasons for Prevalence**

Unauthorized translations thrive due to a lack of enforcement, high import taxes, and a desire for profits. The absence of regulatory mechanisms and a dedicated authority to monitor translation quality contribute to the problem.

**Solutions**

To address this issue, there needs to be increased awareness of copyright laws, enforcement of penalties, and support for authorized translations. Collaboration among publishers, authors, readers, and the government is crucial.

title: Young people from a region where communism was once strong are trying to leave for a better life in the United States but face difficulties.
content:
**Deportation and Debt in Rukum East**

Many young people from Rukum East have illegally migrated to the United States through "backdoor routes," lured by the promise of a better life. However, many have faced deportation and lost large amounts of money in the process.

**Deported Youths:**

**-** Eight deported youths from Tak village have collectively lost Rs45 million.
**-** They returned home empty-handed after facing severe hardships and paying Rs6 million each on average.
**-** The village of Tak, once a Maoist "base area," has lost an estimated Rs40 million to illegal migration.
**-** Some deported youths have fled the village, burdened by debt and facing pressure from creditors.

**Ram Budha's Story:**

**-** Ram Budha returned to Nepal after working in Malaysia for eight years and illegally migrated to the US.
**-** He spent 27 months in a detention camp and was deported, losing Rs4.5 million.
**-** He now owes over Rs6 million to creditors and has moved to Kathmandu to escape the pressure.

**Nanda Kala Gharti's Story:**

**-** Nanda Kala's husband, Dhanlal, illegally migrated to the US and was detained for four years.
**-** Upon deportation, he had lost Rs6 million and is facing a financial crisis.
**-** Nanda Kala fears for her children's future amid the overwhelming debt.

**Other Similar Cases:**

**-** Sisne Rural Municipality has seen similar cases of deportation and financial losses.
**-** Gangaram Khadka, a resident of Sisne, was detained in the US and lost Rs5.2 million in his attempt to seek refugee status.
**-** Tikaram Pun was deported after spending 24 months in detention and is struggling with mental health issues and debt.

**Deaths on the Journey:**

**-** A boat carrying Nepalis and Bangladeshis capsized during an illegal journey to the US, resulting in 12 deaths, including Rupak Bohora.

**Lack of Solutions:**

**-** Local governments and political parties are not addressing the issue of illegal migration.
**-** Poverty and lack of job opportunities are driving young people to seek dangerous and illegal routes to the US.
**-** Human traffickers and "meter byajis" (usurious lenders) are exploiting the situation.
**-** Despite data showing a high number of deportations from the US, complaints are rarely filed with the police.
**-** The Anti-Human Trafficking Bureau lacks specific laws to address this form of human trafficking.

**Gyanumaya BK** has had severe backaches, but she couldn't afford to pay for treatment. She visited Metrocity Hospital, but had to pay Rs. 50,000 for follow-up visits and medications.

Private hospitals in Nepal are required to provide free care to those who can't afford it, but many hospitals are not following this rule.

**Hospital Authorities Admit to Non-Compliance**

The CEO of Metrocity Hospital admits that his hospital does not adhere to the mandate. He says they don't have explicit information from the health ministry.

**Regulatory Bodies Lack Data and Enforcement**

No regulatory body has data on whether health facilities are following government rules. There is not enough manpower to conduct inspections.

**Hospitals Claim to Offer Discounts but Lack Proof**

Hospitals claim to offer discounts on final bills to the needy, but most have not been able to show proof. They are not liable for flouting government standards.

**Patients Ignorant of Their Rights**

Patients like Gyanumaya BK are often unaware that they are entitled to free treatment. Hospitals do not make it easy to access these services.

**Government Regulations Need Amendment**

Private hospitals argue that the current regulations are impractical. They are calling for an amendment to the existing regulations.

**Conclusion**

Private hospitals in Nepal are ignoring government mandates to provide free care to the poor. This is due to a lack of monitoring and enforcement by regulatory bodies, as well as hospitals' desire to make money.

* Support local media financially by subscribing, buying advertising, or making donations.
* Share accurate information from local sources on social media.

content:
**Social Media Regulation in Nepal**

**Current Situation:**

* Nepal is discussing how to regulate social media by bringing it under laws and taxes.
* But there's concern about how to protect our information landscape and hold social media accountable for problems they may cause.

**Importance of Protecting Local Journalism:**

* Local journalism is crucial for democracy and combating misinformation.
* It provides citizens with accurate information and holds those in power accountable.
* Without local journalism, we could face fake news and unqualified leaders.

**Impact of Social Media on Local Journalism:**

* Social media companies don't invest in news production but benefit from sharing it.
* This can hurt local media, especially in developing countries like Nepal.
* Local media houses are increasingly relying on social media to reach audiences.

**What Nepal Can Do:**

* **Strengthen Local Journalism:**

    * Provide financial support, training, and marketing.
    * Create a task force to study the industry and propose solutions.

* **Regulate Social Media Effectively:**

    * Require social media companies to invest in fighting misinformation and hate speech.
    * Ensure they pay taxes and contribute to the information ecosystem.
    * Consider mandating advertisers to spend a portion of their budget on local media.

By taking these steps, Nepal can protect its democracy from misinformation and ensure a balanced information landscape.

content:
**Need to Change Nepal's Electoral System**

Recently, Nepali Congress leaders have emphasized the need to change the current mixed electoral system. They believe it leads to hung parliaments and political instability. Former chief election commissioner Neel Kantha Uprety shared his thoughts on the proposed reforms.

**Factors to Consider:**

When choosing an electoral system, several factors must be considered, including:

* Education level of voters
* Economic conditions
* Social composition (e.g., ethnic communities)
* Geography

**History of Nepal's Electoral Systems:**

* 1959: Nepal adopted the multiparty election system from India.
* 2006: After a people's movement, demands emerged to reform the electoral system to ensure representation of marginalized groups.
* 2008: A mixed electoral system (FPTP and PR) was introduced, increasing representation of women and historically underrepresented groups.

**Anomalies of the Mixed System:**

Leaders have misused the PR system by:

* Promoting family members and loyalists
* Selling seats to wealthy individuals
* Placing close associates at the top of the PR list

**Effectiveness in Ensuring Representation:**

The mixed system has improved representation of women, Dalits, and other marginalized groups, but gaps still exist.

**Possible Solutions:**

* Adopt a fully proportional representation (PR) system
* Implement primaries to select candidates
* Increase the PR vote threshold

**Feasibility of Voting Rights for Nepalis Abroad:**

Technically feasible, but leaders are hesitant due to potential unpredictability in election results.

**Other Proposals:**

* Reserving certain constituencies for women and other marginalized groups
* Electing all National Assembly members through PR and all lower house members through FPTP
* Increasing the PR vote threshold to favor larger parties

**Benefits of Fully PR System:**

* Simplifies and reduces the cost of elections
* Promotes inclusivity and filters out unpopular candidates

title: Muluki Ain is a set of laws.
content:
The Muluki Ain, a legal code from 1854, has been made available online. It received criticism for allegedly promoting the caste system. However, it's important to clarify that the code established a fair and consistent legal system for the entire nation, recognizing the concept of rule of law.

While the caste system was recognized in the code, it was originally based on aptitude and profession, not birth. The code aimed to ensure that laws applied equally to all, regardless of caste. Additionally, it acknowledged the need for reforms and stated that punishment should be consistent for similar offenses, regardless of caste.

It's crucial to note that the Muluki Ain was a legal code, not a document focused solely on social or cultural reforms. However, it did include intentions for such reforms.

title: chhaupadi-persists
content: While feminine issues are addressed every now and then, not everything is taken seriously, and the unspoken issues go unnoticed. Here, I’m not only addressing the horrendous issue of Chhaupadi itself but also speaking of those women and girls who fall prey to this absurd menstrual practice.Ever thought what travelling back in time would feel like? Many in Nepal do not have to imagine, as such old and evil practises continue to occur in the 21st century!Chhaupadi is a flawed tradition connected to the taboo surrounding menstruation that prohibits Hindu menstruators from participating in normal family activities while on their period, as they are considered impure. Although it is said to be practised in the rural part of the country, it does exist in urban areas, too. Going back to its roots, we could perhaps rationalise that women were asked to stay cautious when menstruating because humans were closely surrounded by wildlife. The stench of blood during their period may have made them more vulnerable to attacks from these animals. But even this absurd line of thought doesn't make much sense anymore. The practise was made illegal in 2005, but cases related to it were reported as recent as 2019. News headlines vouched for fatalities on this account. But why are there such trivial punishments for such an offence? Shouldn’t the punishments be rethought to strongly discourage Chhaupadi altogether?Moreover, the reported cases are just the tip of the iceberg. The more you look into it, there are bound to be cases that have gone unreported because nothing immediately tragic occurred. This letter is a call for all of us to come together to fight this social plague. While the legal implications of such an offence are ambiguous, let's collectively decide that the societal implications of it will be grave. Let's refuse to accept such atrocities for our mothers, sisters and, above all, ourselves.Gauri Tandon, via email
